p.text: A party is not to cross-examine a witness who has been called in error by another party and has not been questioned by that other party about a matter relevant to a question to be determined in the proceeding.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 298–299
ALRC 38 para 115(a)
This section is consistent with the position under the general law: GPI Leisure Corp Ltd v Herdsman Investments Pty Ltd (No 3) (1990) 20 NSWLR 15 at 19 .

The court must disallow a question put to a witness in cross-examination, or inform the witness that it need not be answered, if the court is of the opinion that the question (referred to as a disallowable question):
is misleading or confusing, or
is unduly annoying, harassing, intimidating, offensive, oppressive, humiliating or repetitive, or
is put to the witness in a manner or tone that is belittling, insulting or otherwise inappropriate, or
has no basis other than a stereotype (for example, a stereotype based on the witness’s sex, race, culture, ethnicity, age or mental, intellectual or physical disability).
Without limiting the matters the court may take into account for the purposes of subsection (1) , it is to take into account:

any relevant condition or characteristic of the witness of which the court is, or is made, aware, including age, education, ethnic and cultural background, gender, language background and skills, level of maturity and understanding and personality, and
any mental, intellectual or physical disability of which the court is, or is made, aware and to which the witness is, or appears to be, subject, and
the context in which the question is put, including:
the nature of the proceeding, and
in a criminal proceeding — the nature of the offence to which the proceeding relates, and
the relationship (if any) between the witness and any other party to the proceeding.
A question is not a disallowable question merely because:
the question challenges the truthfulness of the witness or the consistency or accuracy of any statement made by the witness, or
the question requires the witness to discuss a subject that could be considered distasteful to, or private by, the witness.
A party may object to a question put to a witness on the ground that it is a disallowable question.
However, the duty imposed on the court by this section applies whether or not an objection is raised to a particular question.

A failure by the court to disallow a question under this section, or to inform the witness that it need not be answered, does not affect the admissibility in evidence of any answer given by the witness in response to the question.
A person must not, without the express permission of a court, print or publish any question that the court has disallowed under this section — see section 195 .
[s 41 subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[12], effective 1 January 2009]
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 300–301, 631
ALRC 38 paras 115(b), 116(a)
ALRC 102 paras 5.70–5.118

A party’s entitlement to cross-examine material witnesses is ordinarily an intrinsic aspect of procedural fairness. It is a significant entitlement whose purpose is to elicit facts or opinions and to test credibility. These ends can, and under the present section must, be achieved without engaging in conduct or using language that would ordinarily be regarded as insulting, offensive or inappropriate: Albrighton v Royal Prince Alfred Hospital [1980] 2 NSWLR 542; see also Mechanical & General Inventions Co v Austin [1935] AC 346 .
Legislation cited in [50,335.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 11, 26(a), s 41, ss 9.

The grounds for objecting to questions put to a witness in cross-examination are wider than the grounds stated in s 41 . They include questions that are ambiguous, argumentative or which call for conclusions. The court has a general discretion to control cross-examination: Mooney v James [1949] VLR 22 at 28 . The power of the court to disallow questions, on grounds other than those for which express provision is made, is preserved by other parts of the Act, such as, ss 9 , 11 and 26(a) .
Legislation cited in [50,335.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 102, s 103.

The credibility rule renders inadmissible evidence that is relevant only to a witness's credibility: see s 102 of the Act. The credibility rule does not apply if the evidence has substantial probative value: see s 103 of the Act.
A party may put a leading question to a witness in cross-examination unless the court disallows the question or directs the witness not to answer it.
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account in deciding whether to disallow the question or give such a direction, it is to take into account the extent to which:
evidence that has been given by the witness in examination in chief is unfavourable to the party who called the witness, and
the witness has an interest consistent with an interest of the cross-examiner, and
the witness is sympathetic to the party conducting the cross-examination, either generally or about a particular matter, and
the witness's age, or any mental, intellectual or physical disability to which the witness is subject, may affect the witness's answers.
The court is to disallow the question, or direct the witness not to answer it, if the court is satisfied that the facts concerned would be better ascertained if leading questions were not used.
This section does not limit the court's power to control leading questions.
“ Leading question ” is defined in the Dictionary.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 302, 632
ALRC 38 paras 115(c), 116(b)
Leading questions are defined in the Dictionary : see also [29.5.75] , [29.5.105] and [50,340.15] .

level.toc-caption: [50,340.15] Disallowance of leading questions in cross-examination

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,340.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 subparas (2)(a), (d), s 42(3).

heading.title: Disallowance of leading questions in cross-examination

p.text: The section confirms the general position that leading questions may be put in cross-examination. But the section also makes clear that the court has the power to require the cross-examination to proceed, either in whole or in relation to particular matters, by the use of non-leading questions. The position was the same at common law: Mooney v James [1949] VLR 22 at 28 per Barry J ("there is no absolute right to put leading questions in cross-examination"). The ultimate criterion (in s 42(3) ) for the exercise of the discretion is merely that the facts concerned would be “better ascertained” if non-leading questions were used. The discretion is appropriate where parties in the same interest could otherwise cross-examine each other's witnesses and, by the process of suggestion inherent in leading questions, elicit unreliable evidence: Dean v Stockland Property Management Pty Limited [2010] NSWCA 66; BC201002179 at [35] . But the discretion conferred in terms of whether evidence would be “better ascertained” is not necessarily confined to such a situation. This is made clear by the criteria in subparas (2)(a) and (d) : see generally Mooney v James [1949] VLR 22 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,345] s 43 Prior inconsistent statements of witnesses

p.text: A witness may be cross-examined about a prior inconsistent statement alleged to have been made by the witness whether or not:
complete particulars of the statement have been given to the witness, or
a document containing a record of the statement has been shown to the witness.

If, in cross-examination, a witness does not admit that he or she has made a prior inconsistent statement, the cross-examiner is not to adduce evidence of the statement otherwise than from the witness unless, in the cross-examination, the cross-examiner:
informed the witness of enough of the circumstances of the making of the statement to enable the witness to identify the statement, and
drew the witness's attention to so much of the statement as is inconsistent with the witness's evidence.
For the purpose of adducing evidence of the statement, a party may re-open the party's case.
ALRC 26 paras 303–306, 636
ALRC 38 para 115(d)
Legislation cited in [50,345.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 cl 6.
Relevant terms defined in the Dictionary include document, previous representation, prior inconsistent statement and representation.
The circumstances in which a witness will be regarded as having made a statement are referred to in cl 6 of Pt 2 of the Dictionary.
Legislation cited in [50,345.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1898 ss 53–55.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 106.

Apart from previous statutory provisions (such as ss 53–55 of the Evidence Act 1898) if a witness had made a prior inconsistent statement in writing the cross-examiner could not make use of the statement unless it was first shown to the witness and put in evidence by the cross-examiner: The Queen's Case (1820) 2 Brod & Bing 284; 129 ER 976; R v Ford (1851) 3 Car & Kir 113; 5 Cox CC 184; Alchin v Cmr for Railways (1935) 35 SR (NSW) 498 ; Maddison v Goldrick [1976] 1 NSWLR 651. The effect of the section, like its predecessors, is to allow a witness to be asked about a prior statement without the statement first being revealed to the witness. The section applies to civil and criminal proceedings: R v Daren [1971] 2 NSWLR 423 at 430; including committal proceedings: Maddison v Goldrick [1976] 1 NSWLR 651. It applies also to both written and oral statements: R v Hart (1958) 42 Cr App R 47. The section confirms that a witness may be cross-examined about a previous inconsistent statement without that statement being given in evidence. The section also makes clear that, unless the prior statement is admitted by the witness, the cross-examining party can adduce evidence of its having been made: R v Hunter [1956] VLR 31; [1955] ALR 786 ; see also s 106 of the Act. Before that evidence can be given, the cross-examiner must have sufficiently identified the statement and drawn the witness's attention to the inconsistency.
Legislation cited in [50,345.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 45.

The cross-examiner can be required (under s 45 of the Act) to produce the document (or evidence of its contents). The court may give directions as to its use and may (assuming that it is otherwise admissible) admit it into evidence whether or not it is tendered by either party.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,350] s 44 Previous representations of other persons

p.text: Except as provided by this section, a cross-examiner must not question a witness about a previous representation alleged to have been made by a person other than the witness.
A cross-examiner may question a witness about the representation and its contents if:
evidence of the representation has been admitted, or
the court is satisfied that it will be admitted.
If subsection (2) does not apply and the representation is contained in a document, the document may only be used to question a witness as follows:
the document must be produced to the witness,

if the document is a tape recording, or any other kind of document from which sounds are reproduced — the witness must be provided with the means (for example, headphones) to listen to the contents of the document without other persons present at the cross-examination hearing those contents,
the witness must be asked whether, having examined (or heard) the contents of the document, the witness stands by the evidence that he or she has given,
neither the cross-examiner nor the witness is to identify the document or disclose any of its contents.
A document that is so used may be marked for identification.
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 636
ALRC 38 paras 115(e), 116(c)
Legislation cited in [50,350.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 cl 6.

Relevant terms defined in the Dictionary include document, previous representation and representation. The circumstances in which a witness will be regarded as having made a representation are referred to in cl 6 of Pt 2 of the Dictionary.

level.toc-caption: [50,350.15] Cross-examination on another person's admissible representations

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,350.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 44, s 44(2).

heading.title: Cross-examination on another person's admissible representations

p.text: Section 44 modifies the common law position under which a witness could not be cross-examined on any documents unless they had been put into evidence: Re Queen’s case (1820) 2 Brod & Bing 284; 129 ER 976; R v Ford (1851) 3 Car & Kir 113; 5 Cox CC 184; Henman v Lester (1862) 12 CB 776; 142 ER 1347 at 1352; R v Gillespie (1967) 51 CAR 172; R v Hollis (1905) 5 SR (NSW) 283; 22 WN (NSW) 83. (A consequence of this requirement was that the document had to be admissible: R v Banks (1916) 12 CAR 74; Paterson v Paterson (1953) 89 CLR 212; [1953] ALR 1095 .) Section 44(2) permits cross-examination on a document that the court is satisfied will be admitted into evidence. Where the subsection applies, it is not necessary that the document actually be shown to the witness. The provisions of s 44(2) are directed solely towards the exclusion for which provision is made in s 44(1): see Stanowski v Commonwealth (2003) 142 A Crim R 90; [2003] NSWSC 1022; BC200306657 . For the purposes of the section, designs and related drawings have been found to be representations: City of Sydney v Streetscape Projects (Aust) Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 942; BC201106426 citing Birchnall v Bullough [1896] 1 QB 325 .

level.toc-caption: [50,350.20] Cross-examination on another person's inadmissible representations

heading.title: Cross-examination on another person's inadmissible representations

p.text: If the admissibility of the document has not been established the cross-examiner may nevertheless show it to the witness and ask whether, having read it, the witness wishes to change the evidence that has been given: R v Roton [1922] VLR 469 ; R v Bedington [1970] Qd R 353 at 359 ; Birchall v Bullough (1896) 1 QB 325 at 326. In so doing the cross-examiner must not identify the document or suggest its contents in any way: R v Sehan (1914) 11 CAR 13 at 18; R v Jack (1894) 15 LR (NSW) 196 . See generally “Cross-Examination on Documents” (1985) 1 Aust Bar Rev 51. It is notable that the fairness of the course of action that the section now expressly authorises was questioned by Gyles QC and McHugh J in (1985) 1 Aust Bar Rev 51 at 69–71 and 72–3 respectively and more recently in R v Hawes (1994) 35 NSWLR 294 at 302–3 .

Whilst the cross-examiner is not required to obtain the permission of the trial judge before showing the witness the document which records the previous representation of the other witness, it would be a breach of the provisions of s 44(2)(b) to reveal the nature and contents of the document being used to confront the witness before attempting to satisfy the court as to its admissibility: see R v S [2003] NSWCCA 122; BC200303688 ; R v Bevan [2002] NSWCCA 224; BC200204537 .

Section 44(3) sets out a particular procedure to be followed, under which cross-examination is limited to asking a witness whether they stand by their evidence, despite the document shown to the witness. If a party seeks to cross-examine for different purposes, such as to explore what the document is and who created it, then the subsection does not apply: City of Sydney v Streetscape Projects (Aust) Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 942; BC201106426 .
Legislation cited in [50,350.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 45.

The cross-examiner can be required (under s 45 of the Act) to produce the document (or evidence of its contents). The court may give directions as to its use and may (assuming that it is otherwise admissible) admit it into evidence whether or not it is tendered by either party.
This section applies if a party is cross-examining or has cross-examined a witness about:
a prior inconsistent statement alleged to have been made by the witness that is recorded in a document, or
a previous representation alleged to have been made by another person that is recorded in a document.
If the court so orders or if another party so requires, the party must produce:
the document, or
such evidence of the contents of the document as is available to the party,
to the court or to that other party.
The court may:
examine a document or evidence that has been so produced, and
give directions as to its use, and
admit it even if it has not been tendered by a party.
Subsection (3) does not permit the court to admit a document or evidence that is not admissible because of Chapter 3 .
The mere production of a document to a witness who is being cross-examined does not give rise to a requirement that the cross-examiner tender the document.
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 636
ALRC 38 paras 115(f), 116(d)
Legislation cited in [50,355.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 45(4), s 45(5).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.6.

At common law if a document was called for and inspected, the party making the call was obliged, if required by the party producing the document, to tender it. In that case, the document was admissible notwithstanding the rule against hearsay: Walker v Walker (1937) 57 CLR 630; 11 ALJR 201 . If, on the other hand, a document was called for and not produced, that failure to produce permitted the party requesting production to adduce secondary evidence of the document’s contents: see Dwyer v Collins (1852) 7 Exch 639; 155 ER 1104 ; Morgan v Babcock and Wilcox Ltd (1929) 43 CLR 163 at 172; 35 ALR 313; 3 ALJR 234 . Section 45(5) makes clear that the obligation to tender the document no longer exists, although any such document which is produced in accordance with this section cannot be tendered unless it is otherwise admissible: see s 45(4) . See generally r 31.6 and the notes thereto.

The court may give leave to a party to recall a witness to give evidence about a matter raised by evidence adduced by another party, being a matter on which the witness was not cross-examined, if the evidence concerned has been admitted and:
it contradicts evidence about the matter given by the witness in examination in chief, or
the witness could have given evidence about the matter in examination in chief.
A reference in this section to a matter raised by evidence adduced by another party includes a reference to an inference drawn from, or that the party intends to draw from, that evidence.
ALRC 26 paras 308, 633–635
ALRC 38 para 115(h)
The court has a general discretion to allow the recall of a witness: see generally [29.5.50] . The section does not remove that discretion.

level.toc-caption: [50,360.15] Leave to recall — the rule in Browne v Dunn

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,360.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 46.

heading.title: Leave to recall — the rule in Browne v Dunn

p.text: Section 46 applies where a party has breached the rule in Browne v Dunn (1893) 6 R 67 by putting in issue a matter after refraining from cross-examination about it. Under the general law, if a witness was not cross-examined on a particular matter, the cross-examining party could be regarded as having accepted the witness's evidence and could be prevented from subsequently addressing the court contrary to the evidence. In exceptional circumstances, the party could be prevented from adducing contrary evidence: Payless Superbarn (NSW) Pty Ltd v O'Gara (1990) 19 NSWLR 551 ; Schneidas v R (No 2) [1981] 2 NSWLR 713; Reid v Kerr (1974) 9 SASR 367. The present section allows the opposing party to recall a witness to deal specifically with the matter: Karidis v General Motors-Holdens Pty Ltd [1971] SASR 422 . But the section is permissive only and does not deal with a number of other aspects of the rule: see D Byrne and J D Heydon, Cross on Evidence, LexisNexis Butterworths, Sydney, 4th ed, at pp 17,162–3. Under the common law, a trial judge confronted with a breach of the rule had a wide discretion as to how to deal with the consequences of a breach of the rule : see Payless Superbarn (NSW) Pty Ltd v O'Gara (1990) 19 NSWLR 551 at 556 per Clarke JA. The section is not intended to operate as a code to the exclusion of common law remedies for a breach of the rule: Darmanin v Cowan [2010] NSWSC 1118; BC201007300 at [109] ff.

For the purposes of the section, the term “witness” refers to a person who is called to give oral evidence. Accordingly, the section does not apply to a situation where a person is sought to be “recalled” to give oral evidence, in circumstances where a statement from him or her had previously been tendered in the proceedings: see Nye v New South Wales (2003) 58 NSWLR 152; [2003] NSWSC 610; BC200303657 (the court retains an inherent / incidental power to permit the witness to be recalled).
